The Internet &klegalnotice;
This chapter contains information on the applications used in order to connect to the Internet. For the purpose of this guide, the term Internet will refer to Web browsers, Email clients, chat clients, and BitTorrent clients.

sect1.title: Web Browsers
sect1.para: The default web browser for Kubuntu is Konqueror. To read more about Konqueror, please review the Konqueror Handbook.
There are many different types of web browsers located in the Ubuntu repositories. From text based browsers to the famous Firefox and Opera browsers, Kubuntu has you covered.

step.para: Open Konqueror by going to &menukonqi;.
Open the Bookmark Editor by going to BookmarksEdit Bookmarks.
In Bookmark Editor go to FileImport.

note.title: Import Options
note.para: You can import IE, Opera, Mozilla, Netscape, KDE2/KDE3, Galeon, as well as All Crash Session bookmarks by selecting the corresponding choice in the Import menu.

step.para: Select the import option that best suits your setup and then close the Bookmark Editor.
Open Konqueror by going to &menukonqi;.
Open the Bookmark Editor by going to BookmarksEdit Bookmarks.
In Bookmark Editor go to FileExport.

note.title: Export Options
note.para: You can export to IE, Opera, Mozilla, Netscape, or HTML bookmarks by selecting the corresponding choice in the Export menu.

step.para: Select the export option that best suits your setup and then close the Bookmark Editor.

sect2.title: Firefox
sect2.subtitle: &menuff;
sect2.para: Firefox 2 is the second generation award-winning Web browser created by Mozilla. Firefox is not installed by default on your Kubuntu system. Please follow the directions below in order to install Firefox.

step.para: Open Add/Remove Programs by going to &menuar;.
When prompted for your password, enter your user password and press OK.
To the right of the Search box is a drop down selection. Select Any Suite.
In the left hand window select Internet.
In the main window select Firefox Web Browser and then press the Apply Changes button.
Once installation is complete press the Quit button to close Add/Remove Programs.
To access Firefox, go to &menuff;.
Open Firefox by going to &menuff;.
Open the Bookmarks Manager by going to BookmarksOrganize Bookmarks....
Open the Import Wizard by going to FileImport...
Under the Import Bookmarks from section select either Opera if you are using Opera or From File to import from other browsers. Once you have selected press Next
You should have been presented the Import Complete step of the Import Wizard. Press the Finish to complete the import.
Close the Bookmarks Manager application.
Access your Opera imports by going to BookmarksFrom Opera and select a bookmark.
Open Firefox by going to &menuff;.
Open the Bookmarks Manager by going to BookmarksOrganize Bookmarks....
Start the export by going to FileExport...
Select the directory you want to save the bookmarks.html and press the Save button.

sect1.title: Email Clients
sect1.para: Options are endless when it comes to email clients for Linux systems. With Kubuntu you are presented with KMail by default either as a standalone or a part of the Kontact personal information manager. Other popular Linux clients include Mozilla Thunderbird, Evolution, Mailody, and even Mutt the command line client.

sect2.title: KMail
sect2.subtitle: &menukontact;
sect2.para:
KMail is the email component of Kontact, the KDE personal information manager. KMail by itself is similar in functionality to the Microsoft Outlook Express application whereas Kontact is as full featured as Microsoft Outlook. The following are just some of the features of KMail.
IMAP, POP3 and SMTP support.
SSL, TLS, and DIGEST-MD5 secure logon support.
PGP and GnuPG signatures and encryption support.
HTML reading, spam filtering, internal character sets, search and filter functions, spell checking, and more.
More information on KMail and configuration can be located in The KMail Handbook. If you plan on using KMail within Kontact also refer to The Kontact Handbook.

sect1.title: Chat Clients
sect1.para: Chatting with friends and family is one of the more popular uses of the Internet. Kubuntu provides you with the necessary applications in order to do so. There are two main chat clients in Kubuntu; Kopete for all of your instant messaging needs and Konversation for chatting on IRC (Internet Relay Chat).

sect2.title: Kopete
sect2.subtitle: &menukopete;
sect2.para:
Kopete is the KDE instant messaging (IM) client. It provides you all of the functionality similar to that of other popular IM clients today. With Kopete you can setup accounts for:
AIM (AOL Instant Messenger)
Gadu-Gadu
GroupWise
ICQ
IRC (Internet Relay Chat)
Jabber
Meanwhile
MSN Messenger
Yahoo
More help is available in the Kopete Handbook.

sect2.title: Konversation
sect2.subtitle: &menukonv;
sect2.para:
Konversation is the KDE IRC (Internet Relay Chat) client for KDE. It provides you a lot of the functionality similar to that of other popular IRC clients today. Some of the included functionality of Konversation is:
User-friendly tabbed interface
Customizable Quick Buttons for often-used commands
Visual and auditory notification for a wide variety of events
On-screen display (OSD) of messages
More help is available in the Konversation Handbook.

sect1.title: BitTorrent Clients
sect1.para: BitTorrent is a peer-to-peer file distribution protocol with a method of distributing vast amounts of data without the control of a middle man. There are many available BitTorrent clients available for use in Kubuntu, however KTorrent is the default application. Other applications available as a BitTorrent client include, but are not limited to, Azureus, BitTornado, BitTorrent and more. Azureus is one of the more popular BitTorrent clients in use today and is created in Java.

sect2.title: KTorrent
sect2.subtitle: &menuktorrent;
sect2.para: KTorrent is a BitTorrent application designed specifically for KDE. Loaded with features, KTorrent is a very functional application that is light on the system and fast on the Internet. To use KTorrent, simply download a .torrent file and KTorrent will automatically recognize the file and start the download. Using KTorrent is very simple and straight forward.

sect3.title: Konqueror
sect3.para: This section will briefly explain the procedure for setting up Konqueror to utilize Java.

step.para: Close Konqueror if it is open.
Install the sun-java6-jre package. For help with installation, please review the Adding Applications documentation.
Start up Konqueror and enjoy.

sect4.title: 32-bit
sect4.para: This section will briefly explain the procedure for setting up Firefox to utilize Java on 32-bit systems.

If you are unsure which processor architecture you are using, simply open Konsole by going to &menukonsole;, and then typing at the prompt uname -a followed by pressing the Enter key. You should see an output similar to the following:
Linux konqi 2.6.22-9-generic #1 SMP Fri Aug 3 00:50:37 GMT 2007 i686 GNU/Linux
The i686 towards the end of the line means that you are using a 32-bit processor. If you see x86_64 instead, then you are using a 64-bit operating system and should see .

step.para: Close Konqueror if it is open.
Install the sun-java6-plugin package. For help with installation, please review the Adding Applications documentation.
Start up Firefox and enjoy.

sect4.title: 64-bit
sect4.para: This section will briefly explain the procedure for setting up Firefox to utilize Java on 64-bit systems.

If you are unsure which installation architecture you are using, simply open Konsole by going to &menukonsole;, and then typing at the prompt uname -a followed by pressing the Enter key. You should see an output similar to the following:
Linux konqi 2.6.22-9-generic #1 SMP Fri Aug 3 00:50:37 GMT 2007 x86_64 GNU/Linux
The x86_64 towards the end of the line means that you are using a 64-bit install. If you see i686 instead, then you are using a 32-bit operating system and should see .

sect2.title: Flash
sect2.para: The Adobe Flash Player can easily be installed for use with Konqueror and/or Firefox by installing the flashplugin-nonfree package. For help with installation, please review the Adding Applications documentation.

note.title: Konqueror's extra step
note.para: Instead of rebooting in order to get Konqueror to see the newly installed plugin, simple restart Konqueror and then go into its configuration (&menukonqi;). Scroll down in the left panel until you see the Plugins icon. In the configuration dialog, press the Scan for New Plugins button. When finished, press the OK button.

sect2.title: Gnash
sect2.para: Gnash is the free software version of the Adobe Flash Player. It is currently in a beta condition and still has issues with many sites who utilize Flash.

sect3.title: Install Gnash for Konqueror
sect3.para: To use the Gnash for Konqueror, simply install the konqueror-plugin-gnash package. For help with installation, please review the Adding Applications documentation. After the installation is complete simply start Konqueror by going to &menukonqi;.

sect3.title: Install Gnash for Firefox
sect3.para: To use Gnash for Firefox, simply install the mozilla-plugin-gnash package. For help with installation, please review the Adding Applications documentation. After the installation is complete, simply start Firefox by going to &menuff;.
